content: To start applying some machine learning models, I'd need to extract a database including all the pairs of equations together with their implication status (e.g. (Equation65,Equation1491,NO)). I'm new to Github and have no idea on how to do this at present. Can this file already be found in the repository? (I didn't find it). Can someone build it and upload it? (In the future, another database including the Lean proof as a field could be needed). Thanks!
Ideally, we'd want the full database, not reduced by transitivity, etc., although it could be nice to have both, in order to compare the difference in efficiencies for the models.
https://tsyrklevich.net/outcomes.json.zip is just the ZIPed output of lake exe extract_implications outcomes
you can determine implicit/explicit yourself using the names in the arrays
@Jose Brox If you have code for loading images, the dashboard contains an always-up-to-date PNG file, and the colors tell you explicit/implicit immediately.
Loading the png is much faster than parsing 18 million JSON entries.

Vlad Tsyrklevich ha dicho:

https://tsyrklevich.net/outcomes.json.zip is just the ZIPed output of lake exe extract_implications outcomes

Thanks! The pairs of equations are not explicit in this file, is it too difficult to generate the file with this data from the project? Just to be sure, these outcomes fix the first equation and range the second one over all equations, including itself, right?
/closure.json.zip is the output of lake exe extract_implications --closure --json which more closely matches that format

Vlad Tsyrklevich schrieb:

/closure.json.zip is the output of lake exe extract_implications --closure --json which more closely matches that format

Vlad, could you please add one more arg to extract_implications, namely the number of entities?

I'd test different approaches on smaller samples first (I could break it down with jq, but I guess more people would profit from having access to samples so that they can experiment with algorithms on their laptops).

(I tried to run the bert+umap script in colab, but the colab environment kept choking)
better to use jq
(deleted)

Zoltan A. Kocsis (Z.A.K.) ha dicho:

Jose Brox If you have code for loading images, the dashboard contains an always-up-to-date PNG file, and the colors tell you explicit/implicit immediately.

Just to be sure, are the rows and columns in increasing order of the equations, with the implication being "row implies column"?
Yes. More accurately, outcomes[i][j] is the information we have about the implication equations[i] => equations[j]
(I was actually thinking about the JSON file, but IIUC the image works the same way)
Jose Brox has marked this topic as resolved.
Jose Brox has marked this topic as unresolved.

Vlad Tsyrklevich ha dicho:

/closure.json.zip is the output of lake exe extract_implications --closure --json which more closely matches that format

In this file there appear equation numbers that make no sense to me. For example, at the start of the implications list, the first pair has as rhs
"Equation374794". There are some other big numers scattered around.

Is there something I am missing, or is this a bug? (We are supposed to have 4694 identities, which squared give the approximate 22 million pairs that there actually are in the file).

There are 4694 equations involving up to four operations, but there are a small number of laws with five or six operations that we are also tracking because they showed up in the literature (you can find a list here). Our numbering system in principle extends to arbitrary length equations, although I don't think we've actually run the relevant script past six operations. I assume there is some way to strip these longer equations out of the extract_implications script.

Terence Tao ha dicho:

There are 4694 equations involving up to four operations, but there are a small number of laws with five or six operations that we are also tracking because they showed up in the literature (you can find a list [here]

Ah, of course! Thank you!
Jose Brox has marked this topic as resolved.
